channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 The New York Times Company

item.title: Hong Kong Police, Seen as ‘Hounds After Rabbits,’ Face Rising Rage
item.description: The shooting of a teenage protester has amplified anger at a police force that some see as a symbol of Beijing’s unchecked power.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong and Tiffany May
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Riot police officers clash with protesters in Wong Tai Sin in Hong Kong on Tuesday.

item.title: Cyberattacks on Egyptian Activists Are Traced to Government
item.description: A cybersecurity firm says evidence suggests the Egyptian government carried out cyberattacks on journalists, academics, lawyers and rights activists.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman and Declan Walsh
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A protest in Cairo last month calling for the removal of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi.

item.title: Knife Attack at Paris Police Headquarters Kills at Least 4 Officers
item.description: The assailant was also killed, officials said. His motive was not immediately clear.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: French officers secured the area in front of Police Headquarters in Paris after the knife attack on Thursday.

item.title: First Barr, Now Pompeo: Italy Is Hub of Impeachment Intrigue for Trump Officials
item.description: Visits to Italy by Attorney General William Barr and Secretary of State Mike Pompeo, central figures in the impeachment inquiry consuming Washington, have raised questions about their trips’ purpose.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo during a private tour of the Vatican, on Wednesday. From left, his wife, Susan Pompeo; a Vatican curator; and Callista Gingrich, the ambassador to the Holy See.

item.title: El Chapo Said to Have Given $1 Million to Honduran President’s Brother
item.description: The president — who has not been charged in the case — has faced suspicion as United States prosecutors alleged recently he was part of the conspiracy in which his brother was charged.
item.dc:creator: Emily Palmer and Benjamin Weiser
item.media:description: Juan Antonio (Tony) Hernández, the younger brother of the Honduran president, Juan Orlando Hernández, in March.

item.title: Christchurch Shooting Suspect Drops Bid to Move Trial to Auckland
item.description: The man accused of killing 51 people in a terrorist attack on two mosques in New Zealand will be tried in the city where the shooting occurred, after his legal team withdrew a bid for a new venue.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Graham-McLay
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: The courthouse in Christchurch, New Zealand, where the suspect in the March 2019 mosque attacks entered a not-guilty plea in June.

item.title: ‘Just Give Us a Country’: Thousands in Iraq Protest Corruption
item.description: On the second day of antigovernment protests, the security forces responded with tear gas and bullets, leaving at least two people dead.
item.dc:creator: Falih Hassan and Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:description: Protesters clashed on Tuesday with riot police officers in Baghdad during a demonstration against state corruption and poor services.

item.title: Shooting in Sydney Raises Questions About Gun Control
item.description: A gunman was shot dead by the police Wednesday after an hourlong shooting spree across western Sydney targeting a home and two police stations.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave

item.title: Putin Says He Doesn’t Mind if Private Talk With Trump Is Made Public
item.description: Days after his spokesman said the leaders’ chats should remain secret, Mr. Putin said he had nothing to hide, and made light of charges of election interference.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: President Trump with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Helsinki, Finland, in July. Mr. Trump, has adopted a friendlier stance toward Moscow than his predecessors.

item.title: Facebook Encryption Eyed in Fight Against Online Child Sex Abuse
item.description: The debate over privacy in the digital age increasingly pits tech companies against law enforcement agencies as explicit imagery explodes.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Valentino-DeVries and Gabriel J.X. Dance
item.media:credit: Kholood Eid for The New York Times
item.media:description: A digital forensics work space at Kansas’s task force for internet crimes against children.

item.title: French Police Protest en Masse: ‘It’s About the Lack of Respect’
item.description: About 27,000 French police officers demonstrated, according to union officials, driven by frustration over working conditions, public image and a wave of suicides this year.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.media:description: Police unions said that about 27,000 people turned out to protest poor working conditions.

item.title: China’s Spenders Are Saving. That’s a Problem for Everyone.
item.description: Chinese consumers, a $4.9 trillion force, transformed the global economy. With their own economy slowing, they are pulling back.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Younger Chinese have never experienced a prolonged economic downturn; now they worry about the future.

item.title: Boris Johnson: ‘I Love Europe’ and Here Is My Plan to Leave It
item.description: The swift, negative response of Irish officials to the plan by the British prime minister suggested that it would not draw the two sides any closer to an amicable divorce.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s gleefully combative tone at the Conservative Party conference in Manchester, England, seemed calculated to mobilize the party for an election.

item.title: To Disrupt Elections, Taliban Turn to an Old Tactic: Destroying Cell Towers
item.description: The insurgent group’s strategy of disrupting cellular communication highlights the delicate balance of fighting the government while trying to gain support from the rural populace.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Najim Rahim
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Election workers at a warehouse in Kabul on Monday. Many voters complained they could not find their names at polling stations where they had signed up to vote.

item.title: One Year On, Shadow of Khashoggi’s Killing Stalks Saudi Prince
item.description: Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia is trying to regain his international footing after the killing of Jamal Khashoggi at the Saudi Consulate in Istanbul.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Prince Mohammed bin Salman, Saudi Arabia’s de facto leader, is ramping up efforts to regain his lost international standing, accepting some responsibility for the killing and vowing not to repeat his missteps.

item.title: Boeing 737 Max Safety System Was Vetoed, Engineer Says
item.description: The company passed on the concerns to the Department of Justice as part of a criminal investigation into the engineering of the plane after two fatal crashes.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff, David Gelles and Jack Nicas
item.media:description: A Boeing 737 Max in Renton, Wash. The company’s best-selling model remains grounded after two fatal crashes.

item.title: North Korean Missile Delivers a Message: There’s Little Japan Can Do
item.description: The launch reinforced how deeply Japan has been sidelined as President Trump tries to restart nuclear talks with North Korea despite a string of missile tests.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:description: A screen in Tokyo reporting North Korea’s missile launch on Wednesday, the first in nearly two years to land in Japan’s exclusive economic zone, which extends 200 miles off its coast.

item.title: Pompeo Confirms He Listened to Trump’s Call to Ukraine President
item.description: “I was on the phone call,” the American secretary of state said at a news conference in Rome — the first time he has addressed the topic publicly.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry

item.title: Man Confesses to Brutal Killings That Terrorized South Korea, Police Say
item.description: A 56-year-old man has confessed to raping and murdering 14 women more than two decades ago, the police said in naming the suspect.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: Investigators in 1993 searching a scene thought to be related to a string of killings in Hwaseong, South Korea. A 56-year-old man has confessed to being involved in those killings, the police said.

item.title: Hong Kong Protests Led a Student to Activism, Then to the Point of a Gun
item.description: Tsang Chi-kin, 18, showed no interest in politics until this year. After being shot by the police, he could become a potent symbol of the protests.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher, Mike Ives and Elaine Yu

item.title: Who’s in Charge in Peru? Peruvians Can’t Agree
item.description: The president dissolved Congress. Congress suspended the president. Now the vice president has renounced. Here’s what you need to know to understand the dysfunction roiling Peru.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Andrea Zarate
item.media:description: Riot police surrounding Congress and blocking traffic in downtown Lima on Tuesday. Many businesses along the main avenues remained closed.

item.title: Hong Kong Police Shot a Protester at Point-Blank Range. We Break Down What Happened.
item.description: In a major escalation of violence since protests began four months ago, the Hong Kong police fired a live round at a protester from point-blank range. We analyzed the footage to create a comprehensive picture of what exactly happened.
item.dc:creator: Haley Willis and Ainara Tiefenthäler

item.title: Ukraine? Impeachment? Trump Can Survive It All, Foreign Analysts Say
item.description: The notion of this president demanding political favors from fellow leaders is such familiar behavior it fails to elicit much shock.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.category: Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry
item.media:description: President Trump at the United Nations General Assembly last month.

item.title: Meghan, Duchess of Sussex, Sues Mail on Sunday Over Publication of Letter
item.description: In a statement, the duchess’s husband, Prince Harry, said that the letter was published unlawfully and was part of a “ruthless campaign” by British tabloids.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller and Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: Meghan, the duchess of Sussex, with Prince Harry and their son, Archie, in South Africa last month.

item.title: Two Killed in Anti-Government Protests in Iraq
item.description: The protests were the most serious against Prime Minister Adel Abdul Mahdi’s government since it was formed a year ago.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.media:description: A demonstration against state corruption and poor services in Baghdad on Tuesday.

item.title: Protests Erupt in Hong Kong, Overshadowing China’s National Day Parade
item.description: The contrast of National Day pageantry in Beijing versus anti-government mayhem in Hong Kong was almost certainly infuriating to President Xi Jinping.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Mike Ives and Steven Lee Myers

item.title: India Isn’t Letting a Single Onion Leave the Country
item.description: India’s government bans the export of onions in order to lower rising domestic prices, causing great pain to neighboring countries.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman, Julfikar Ali Manik and Suhasini Raj
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: An onion market in Lasalgaon, near Nashik, India.

item.title: Brother of Iran’s President Is Sentenced to Prison for Corruption
item.description: President Hassan Rouhani campaigned on a promise to fight corruption, but long-running accusations against his brother have undermined him politically.
item.dc:creator: Michael Wolgelenter
item.media:description: Hossein Fereydoun, brother of President Hassan Rouhani of Iran.

item.title: Parliament Speaker in Nepal Resigns After Rape Accusation
item.description: After a parliamentary employee accused Krishna Bahadur Mahara of raping her, the governing Communist Party forced him to step down. He denies the accusations.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma
item.media:description: Krishna Bahadur Mahara, left, will retain his seat in Parliament.

item.title: Hours After Agreeing to Resume Talks, North Korea Launches Missile
item.description: North Korea launched the missiles shortly after saying it would restart stalled talks with the United States over its nuclear weapons program.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and David E. Sanger
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: President Trump and the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, at the Demilitarized Zone between North and South Korea in June.

item.title: As Boris Johnson’s Time to Get Brexit Deal Ticks Down, Blame Game Heats Up
item.description: Officials in Brussels, Dublin and London question whether the prime minister is more serious about striking a deal, or about averting blame if talks fail.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, center, has dismissed the prospect of having most of the United Kingdom operate under one trade system, while Northern Ireland remains tied to a different set of rules.

item.title: The Long-Ignored Athens Waterfront Is Being Revived
item.description: At the heart of the Faliro Bay Restoration Project is a 50-acre park being designed by the architect Renzo Piano near sites of the 2004 Olympics.
item.dc:creator: Pavlos Zafiropoulos
item.media:credit: Myrto Papadopoulos for The New York Times
item.media:description: A party at Island, an upscale restaurant, nightclub and event space in Varkiza, a southeast Athens suburb. Developers envision an international clientele for the seafront.

item.title: Hong Kong Police Shoot a Protester, 18, With a Live Bullet for the First Time
item.description: The escalation in police tactics came amid violent demonstrations on National Day, a holiday commemorating Communist Party rule in China.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives

item.title: Peru’s President Dissolves Congress, and Lawmakers Suspend Him
item.description: President Martín Vizcarra of Peru plunged the government into uncertainty as he tried to force new elections and overcome lawmakers’ efforts to block his anticorruption agenda.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Andrea Zarate
item.media:description: Demonstrators celebrating after President Martín Vizcarra dissolved the legislature in Lima, Peru, on Monday.

item.title: The Best Movies and TV Shows New on Netflix Canada in October
item.description: Every month, Netflix Canada adds a batch of movies and TV shows to its library. Here are the titles we think are most interesting for October.
item.dc:creator: Scott Tobias

item.title: How Iran’s President Left Trump Hanging, and Macron in the Hall
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron of France tried to broker a call in the New York hotel where Iran’s president, Hassan Rouhani, was staying. President Trump wanted to talk. Mr. Rouhani declined.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi and Rick Gladstone
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani of Iran addressed the United Nations General Assembly on Wednesday.

item.title: Shuping Wang, Who Helped Expose China’s Rural AIDS Crisis, Dies at 59
item.description: She braved ostracism, assault and the loss of her job to expose the spread of the disease in rural China. A play about her has opened in London.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: Shuping Wang defied Chinese officials who tried to hide an AIDS epidemic in rural China. She helped expose the spread of H.I.V. through shoddy facilities that bought blood from poor farmers.

item.title: Lebanon’s Prime Minister Gave $16 Million to South African Model
item.description: Saad Hariri did not make the payments while he was prime minister, South African court records show, but the revelation is likely to tarnish his image.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Prime Minister Saad Hariri of Lebanon in Beirut in August. He gave more than $16 million to a South African model who said they had a relationship.

item.title: Moroccan Journalist Sentenced to Prison for Abortion and Premarital Sex
item.description: A doctor convicted of performing the abortion was sentenced, along with Hajar Raissouni and her fiancé. They denied any abortion had taken place.
item.dc:creator: Aida Alami
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A protest against the prosecution of Hajar Raissouni in front of the Rabat courthouse this month.

item.title: Both Afghan Candidates Claim the Lead Even Before Votes Are Tallied
item.description: The clashing claims by President Ashraf Ghani and rival Abdullah Abdullah could set up a political crisis, some fear.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Fahim Abed
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abdullah Abdullah, center, a top contender in the presidential election, claimed victory in Kabul on Monday, but vote counting is in the early stages.

item.title: Thousands in Indonesia Protest Bills to Limit Rights and Ban Extramarital Sex
item.description: President Joko Widodo faces pressure to revoke a law curbing anti-graft efforts and to kill measures that would forbid abortion and sex outside marriage.
item.dc:creator: Richard C. Paddock and Muktita Suhartono
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.media:description: A protest on Monday in Denpasar, on the resort island of Bali, against measures to ban sex outside of marriage and weaken Indonesia’s anti-graft agency.

item.title: Riots Erupt at Greek Migrant Camp on Lesbos After Deadly Fire
item.description: The authorities said the situation had stabilized, but others saw a need for more urgent action at the chronically overcrowded facilities.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:description: Fleeing clashes with the police on the Greek island of Lesbos on Sunday.

item.title: Car Bombers in Somalia Hit U.S. and European Military Bases
item.description: The extremist group known as the Shabab claimed responsibility for an attack on an American base used to launch airstrikes against the group.
item.dc:creator: Richard Pérez-Peña
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The scene of an attack on an Italian military convoy in Mogadishu on Monday.

item.title: France Honors Jacques Chirac With a Day of Mourning
item.description: World leaders gathered in Paris for a final tribute to the fondly remembered former French president, who died last week at age 86.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: The body of former President Jacques Chirac was carried out of the Invalides monument in Paris on Monday.

item.title: Xi Extols China’s ‘Red’ Heritage in a Land Haunted by Famine Under Mao
item.description: Seventy years after Mao founded the People’s Republic, Xi Jinping visited Xinyang to rekindle revolutionary traditions. Its survivors of mass starvation went unmentioned.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.media:description: A farmer in Gaodadian Village in the Xinyang region of Henan Province. 60 years ago, over half of the villagers in Gaodadian starved to death as a result of Mao’s Great Leap forward.

item.title: U.S. Sees Rising Threat in the West From Qaeda Branch in Syria
item.description: American counterterrorism officials are voicing alarm about a Qaeda affiliate in Syria that they say is plotting attacks from the country’s northwest.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:credit: Omar Haj Kadour/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Rescue crews searching the rubble of a building in April after an explosion in Idlib Province, Syria. The province contains a witch’s brew of extremist groups.

item.title: Boris Johnson Still Basks in Favor of Hard-Line Tories, Who Forgive All for Brexit
item.description: In London, the British prime minister seems to be facing one crisis after another. But in Manchester, where his Conservative party is meeting, it’s another story altogether.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain arriving Sunday for the Conservative party conference in Manchester, England.

item.title: Top Bodyguard to 2 Saudi Kings Is Shot Dead
item.description: Gen. Abdulaziz al-Faghem, who oversaw protection for two Saudi kings, was shot and killed in what the Saudi news media called a personal dispute.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Gen. Abdulaziz al-Faghem, left, in 2015 with King Salman of Saudi Arabia, whom he often guarded. General al-Faghem also guarded the previous king.

item.title: Kurz Wins Austria Election. Will He Turn to Far Right or Greens to Govern?
item.description: Sebastian Kurz, who came in first in a snap election in Austria, has a choice: Partner again with the far-right party that collapsed his government or shift left?
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:description: Sebastian Kurz, who was Austria’s chancellor from late 2017 until May, speaking to the media after voting on Sunday.

item.title: As Deadly Floods Engulf Nepal Border, Anger Turns to India
item.description: Nepal said embankments built by India along a shared border made flooding worse in their country during the summer monsoon season, killing dozens.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma and Kai Schultz
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: People walking in the rain along an embankment built by India at the border it shares with Nepal.

item.title: Luxury Cars Seized From African Leader’s Son Are Auctioned in Geneva
item.description: Vehicles linked to an inquiry into graft in Equatorial Guinea yielded $27 million at auction.
item.dc:creator: Iliana Magra
item.media:description: Supercars from a collection owned by a son of Equatorial Guinea’s president were shown on Friday at an auction preview in the Swiss village of Cheserex.

item.title: Unveiling Monument to Migrants, Pope Francis Urges Compassion for Refugees
item.description: The pope unveiled the sculpture in St. Peter’s Square during a special Mass and portrayed migration as an opportunity to “promote the integral human development of all people.”
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis unveiled “Angels Unaware,” a sculpture by the Canadian artist Timothy Schmalz representing displaced people throughout history, on Sunday in St. Peter’s Square.

item.title: Revisiting Hitler, in a New Authoritarian Age
item.description: With nationalism and anti-Semitism on the rise around the world, two big new biographies look at the Nazi leader’s march to power.
item.dc:creator: Talya Zax
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Hitler outside party headquarters in 1931. The biographers Peter Longerich and Brendan Simms have new books about his rise to power.

item.title: U.S. Businesswoman Admitted Affair With Boris Johnson, U.K. Report Says
item.description: The woman, Jennifer Arcuri, reportedly told friends that she was having an affair with Mr. Johnson when he was mayor, deepening the scandal as he tries to navigate an impasse over Brexit.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: Boris Johnson, center, then the mayor of London, and Jennifer Arcuri, left, at a conference in the British capital in 2014.

item.title: Major Clashes Erupt in Hong Kong Ahead of China’s National Day
item.description: The demonstrations openly defy Beijing’s rule just two days before the central government celebrates 70 years of Communist rule.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives, Keith Bradsher and Andrew Jacobs
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: The riot police detaining a protester near the government’s offices.
